item.title: US emissions jumped in 2025 as coal power rebounded
item.description: WASHINGTON — The United States’ greenhouse gas emissions increased by 2.4% in 2025 after two years of decline amid a resurgence of coal power, according to estimates published Tuesday by the Rhodium Group, a research firm.
item.source:markdown: WASHINGTON — The United States’ greenhouse gas emissions increased by 2.4% in 2025 after two years of decline amid a resurgence of coal power, according to estimates published Tuesday by the Rhodium Group, a research firm.

item.title: US senators introduce long-awaited bill to define crypto market rules
item.description: U.S. senators late on Monday unveiled draft legislation that would create ‌a regulatory framework for cryptocurrency which, if signed into law, would clarify financial regulators’ jurisdiction over the burgeoning sector, potentially boosting digital asset adoption.

item.title: Hilo protest draws hundreds in remembrance of Renee Good
item.description: Over 300 residents gathered Saturday across from the King Kamehameha statue at Bayfront Park in Hilo to protest the killing of Renee Nicole Good, a 37-year-old mother of three who was fatally shot by an Immigration and Customs Enforcement officer in a Minneapolis residential neighborhood last Thursday.

item.title: Digicel PNG secure exclusive broadcast rights for rugby league world cup
item.description:
Digicel (PNG) Limited is thrilled to announce that it has secured the exclusive broadcast and digital rights for the Rugby League World Cup 2026 (RLWC2026), proudly becoming the Official Home of the tournament in Papua New Guinea.

This landmark agreement underscores Digicel’s unwavering commitment to rugby league and its mission to connect fans across PNG and the Pacific to the pinnacle of international competition.

item.title: Jayson Sablan reflects on coastal change in ‘Ta Na’i Ånimu II: Sacred Waters’
item.description: By Ron Rocky Coloma On Saipan’s coastlines, change often arrives quietly. It shows up in familiar fishing spots, gathering places and shorelines that feel unchanged until they are not. That slow realization sits at the center of photographer Jayson Sablan’s work, now on view at the Guam Museum as part of an exhibition that blends art, memory and environmental concern. More than 35 artists from across the Mariana Islands are participating in “Ta Na’i Ånimu II: Sacred Waters,” which opened...

item.title: Tkatchenko reaffirmed diplomatic ties with China
item.description:
Foreign Affairs Minister Justin Tkatchenko has reaffirmed that Papua New Guinea will continue to strengthen its diplomatic relationship with China, its biggest economic and trade partners, on Friday, January 9th, 2026

In a meeting with Ambassador of the People's Republic of China, His Excellency Yang Xiaoguang, the first for the year, Minister Tkatchenko emphasized PNG's commitment to continue to work together to grow relations and opportunities that will benefit both the people, the produce and the business sector.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

item.title: Marape flags cabinet re-alignment
item.description:
Prime Minister James Marape has announced that his government is entering a period of performance-based Cabinet realignment as Papua New Guinea moves into what he described as a decisive “year of reset” following the nation’s 50th Independence anniversary.

Speaking at Government House after the swearing-in of Kompiam-Ambum MP Sir John Pundari, Tewai-Siassi MP Dr Kobby Bomareo and Menyamya MP Solen Loifa as Ministers of State, Prime Minister Marape said the appointments were both a recognition of political balance in the coalition and a strategic move to strengthen government delivery in 2026.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Marape flags cabinet re-alignment appeared first on Post Courier.
item.source:markdown:
![](https://www.postcourier.com.pg/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/PM-3.png?w=800)
Prime Minister James Marape has announced that his government is entering a period of performance-based Cabinet realignment as Papua New Guinea moves into what he described as a decisive “year of reset” following the nation’s 50th Independence anniversary.
Speaking at Government House after the swearing-in of Kompiam-Ambum MP Sir John Pundari, Tewai-Siassi MP Dr Kobby Bomareo and Menyamya MP Solen Loifa as Ministers of State, Prime Minister Marape said the appointments were both a recognition of political balance in the coalition and a strategic move to strengthen government delivery in 2026.

item.title: PC Online Tidbits
item.description:
Visible from space. Goodness!
Our same Henao Drive road from above, we took screenshots of from Google Earth. Guess what. It can be viewed from space. We were right after all. The heavens will have to come down fix this bad road. To make matters worse there is one State Minister and another two MPs that live in the same area, that includes the current Opposition leader. As we said, there needs to be divine intervention here, as even the car dodging the potholes are clearly captured from space all over the place. We thought it was a three-lane road!

The post PC Online Tidbits appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: Banks warn consumers will be hurt by Trump’s 10% cap on credit card interest rates
item.description: U.S. banks and financial institutions on Monday pushed back against President Donald Trump’s proposed cap on credit card interest rates, citing new data that showed it would result in millions of American households and small businesses losing access to credit. Trump, who is ‍under pressure to address voter concerns over the cost of living, on Friday called for a one-year cap on credit card interest rates at 10% starting on January 20. He did not provide details on how such a ban would be imposed, and some industry experts said it would require congressional action.
item.source:markdown: U.S. banks and financial institutions on Monday pushed back against President Donald Trump’s proposed cap on credit card interest rates, citing new data that showed it would result in millions of American households and small businesses losing access to credit. Trump, who is ‍under pressure to address voter concerns over the cost of living, on Friday called for a one-year cap on credit card interest rates at 10% starting on January 20. He did not provide details on how such a ban would be imposed, and some industry experts said it would require congressional action.

item.title: Trump administration has revoked over 100,000 visas, State Department says
item.description: WASHINGTON — The U.S. State Department said on Monday it has ​revoked more ‌than 100,000 visas since President Donald Trump took ‌office last year, setting what it said was a new record as his administration pursues its hardline immigration policy.
item.source:markdown: WASHINGTON — The U.S. State Department said on Monday it has ​revoked more ‌than 100,000 visas since President Donald Trump took ‌office last year, setting what it said was a new record as his administration pursues its hardline immigration policy.

item.title: Obituaries for January 13
item.description: Jafra Lehua Kahealani Depontes, 43, of Kailua-Kona died Oct. 24. She was a loving daughter, wife and mother. Visitation 10:30-11:30 a.m. Sunday, Jan. 18 at Kahaluu Ma Kai. Celebration of life service at 11:30 a.m. Luncheon to follow. Survived by husband, Andrew; daughters, Kilihea, Anaha, One‘ula; father, Jayme (Sabine) Depontes; mother Liane Depontes; brother, Nainoa (Emily) Depontes; stepbrothers. Kane Depontes and Ryan Depontes; grandmother, Nita Depontes; aunts, uncles, a nephew and cousins. Arrangements by Nuuanu Memorial Park and Mortuary.
item.source:markdown: Jafra Lehua Kahealani Depontes, 43, of Kailua-Kona died Oct. 24. She was a loving daughter, wife and mother. Visitation 10:30-11:30 a.m. Sunday, Jan. 18 at Kahaluu Ma Kai. item.title: Kelly sues Pentagon over threats of punishment from Hegseth
item.description: WASHINGTON — Sen. Mark Kelly, D-Ariz., on Monday sued Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth and the Pentagon over a move to punish him for a video he released with other lawmakers reminding military members that they must not follow illegal orders.
item.source:markdown: WASHINGTON — Sen. Mark Kelly, D-Ariz., on Monday sued Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth and the Pentagon over a move to punish him for a video he released with other lawmakers reminding military members that they must not follow illegal orders.

item.title: European commissioner says US military takeover of Greenland would be end of NATO
item.description: SALEN, Sweden — The European Union can help provide security for Greenland, should Denmark request it, the European Commissioner for Defense and Space said on Monday, warning that a U.S. military takeover of Greenland would be the end of NATO.
item.source:markdown: SALEN, Sweden — The European Union can help provide security for Greenland, should Denmark request it, the European Commissioner for Defense and Space said on Monday, warning that a U.S. military takeover of Greenland would be the end of NATO.

item.title: Re-create Anthony Bourdain’s Beef Bourguignon
item.description: One benefit of being a food editor is that I get the opportunity to try out recipes from the latest cookbooks, often before they have even made it onto store shelves. It keeps me on my toes with what’s trending, and over the years it has had the fringe benefit of greatly expanding my culinary skills.

item.title: The Warisan blueprint: How PNG’s greatest keeper shaped Hekari’s new captain
item.description:
When PNG Hekari FC embarks on its historic journey into the inaugural OFC Pro League season, they will do so under the leadership of a man who defines patience and purpose: goalkeeper Dave Tomare.

The 28-year-old Central Bougainville man has been officially appointed to captain the "Red Army," a milestone that marks his transition from a promising recruit to the undisputed general of the pitch.

item.title: NFS to host OFC Pro league round two
item.description:
The Oceania Football Confederation can confirm that the Santos National Football Stadium in Port Moresby will host all matches in Round 2 of the OFC Pro League in Papua New Guinea.

 This series of elite regional fixtures is set to begin on Saturday, January 31, with Vanuatu United FC facing Tahiti United, followed by a marquee matchup between home side PNG Hekari FC and Auckland FC.

item.title: Lloyds Metals continues community support through new donation
item.description:
In a major boost for healthcare in Central Bougainville, Lloyds Metals and Energy Ltd (LMEL) has donated a critical consignment of medical supplies to Arawa District Hospital (ADH), addressing a chronic drug shortage that has plagued the facility for years.

The donation comes at a time when the Autonomous Region of Bougainville (AROB) health sector is facing significant logistical challenges. For many patients at Arawa Hospital, a lack of basic medicine has meant receiving prescriptions only to be forced to buy them at expensive private pharmacies, with some even traveling as far as Buka to find essential drugs.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Lloyds Metals continues community support through new donation appeared first on Post Courier.
item.source:markdown:
![](https://www.postcourier.com.pg/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/Dilip-Harischandra-Burade-2nd-from-right-presenting-the-medical-supplies-to-Arawa-Hospital-aCEO-Mr-Ignatius-Giranah-and-Gwen-Kolonga-ADH-Pharmacist-far-right.-.png?w=800)

item.title: Kokoda leaders reconcile to foster unity and progress
item.description:
In a significant move for political stability in Central Bougainville, former Member for Kokoda, Rodney Osioco, and the incumbent Member, Philip Pinaung, have officially reconciled.

The reconciliation ceremony took place on Sunday at their home village of Sirovai, effectively ending a period of tension that followed a misunderstanding between their respective supporters during the last Autonomous Bougainville Government (ABG) elections.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Kokoda leaders reconcile to foster unity and progress appeared first on Post Courier.

In a significant move for political stability in Central Bougainville, former Member for Kokoda, Rodney Osioco, and the incumbent Member, Philip Pinaung, have officially reconciled.

item.title: Lae gets 250 new rubbish drums as businesses and authority team up to clean streets
item.description:
Lae residents will soon see 250 new galvanized rubbish drums placed around the city, a joint initiative between Barlow Industries Limited and the Lae City Authority (LCA).

Each drum can hold at least 300 litres of waste. The aim is to make it easier for residents to dispose of rubbish responsibly and keep the city clean.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

item.title: The Americans prosecuted for voting
item.description: The terms “nationality” and “citizenship” are generally used interchangeably. For example, the 14th Amendment's Citizenship Clause is codified in the U.S. Immigration and Nationality Act as the status of “national and citizen.”

item.title: Rain and Flood warnings issued for regions across PNG
item.description:
With Cyclone Koji hitting North Queensland, causing heavy rain and flooding, the Papua New Guinea National Weather Service has also issued heavy rain and flood warnings for regions across the country.

The Weather Service has issued warnings for the Eastern Highlands, West New Britain, Bougainville, Madang, Morobe, Western Province, and Oro Province for the next 24 hours.

item.title: Amata’s awareness PSA reminds U.S. Nationals not to vote in other jurisdictions
item.description:
Source: Congresswoman Uifa’atali Amata’s D.C. staff

Washington, D.C. — (January 9, 2026) Congresswoman Uifa’atali Amata is reminding U.S. nationals from American Samoa that under current U.S. and state laws they absolutely cannot vote in elections outside of American Samoa unless they personally become U.S. citizens before voting. 

“It’s incredibly important to not become confused over this: U.S. nationals cannot vote outside our elections in American Samoa. Even if the poll workers do not stop you from voting, and you have a state driver’s license, it’s still not allowed, and can lead to huge legal problems,” said Congresswoman Amata. “If you want to vote in the United States, you must become a citizen first, even if you’ve lived in a U.S. community for many years.”

“Until we are certain that we have widespread 100 percent awareness of this fact, it’s helpful to have a reminder to be sure the word is out, and protect friends and family from a legal nightmare. It’s very important to make sure your graduating high schoolers who are still U.S. nationals know this clearly when they turn 18 and potentially go away to jobs and college,” Aumua Amata continued. “For those choosing citizenship, I have a bill to help that process for U.S. nationals, but nationals risk prosecution by voting in any state that requires U.S. citizenship to be eligible to vote, unless state law were to expressly provide that U.S. nationals also may vote in that state’s elections.”

Amata has introduced the American Samoa Statutory Nationality and Citizenship Act (H.R. 6158) to help individual U.S. nationals more readily transfer into U.S. citizenship as a personal choice, while not affecting American Samoa’s current status, which for over 125 years has protected the family land and chiefly (matai) systems within the traditional fa’a Samoa (Samoan way). 

The bill protects both collective self-determination for American Samoa and the individual rights of U.S. nationals, by enabling elective United States citizenship for individuals, and she will be posting more information about the bill in the months ahead. 

“I am saddened by the voting case in Alaska, and I hope the wonderful people of Alaska, where I’ve visited many times, will be forgiving of this mistake by the local U.S. nationals in their community,” Amata concluded. “Rather, I hope that this can become an educational moment, that the Lord can ‘work together for good’ by preventing future problems through public awareness while restoring our people in Alaska with compassion.” 

 

 

Section: 
Local News
Tags: 
Congresswoman Uifa’atali Amata
item.source:markdown:
[![us national passport](https://www.samoanews.com/sites/default/files/styles/slideshow/public/field/image/national_passport_2.jpg?itok=lz7egqBt)](https://www.samoanews.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_normal_image/public/field/image/national_passport_2.jpg?itok=F3N61JSd)

“It’s incredibly important to not become confused over this: U.S. nationals cannot vote outside our elections in American Samoa. Even if the poll workers do not stop you from voting, and you have a state driver’s license, it’s still not allowed, and can lead to huge legal problems,” said Congresswoman Amata. “If you want to vote in the United States, you must become a citizen first, even if you’ve lived in a U.S. community for many years.”
“Until we are certain that we have widespread 100 percent awareness of this fact, it’s helpful to have a reminder to be sure the word is out, and protect friends and family from a legal nightmare. It’s very important to make sure your graduating high schoolers who are still U.S. nationals know this clearly when they turn 18 and potentially go away to jobs and college,” Aumua Amata continued. “For those choosing citizenship, I have a bill to help that process for U.S. nationals, but nationals risk prosecution by voting in any state that requires U.S. citizenship to be eligible to vote, unless state law were to expressly provide that U.S. nationals also may vote in that state’s elections.”

item.title: Virtual event today as comment period for Deep Sea Mining in Am Samoa closes
item.description:
Source: Right to Democracy Press Release

Pago Pago, AMERICAN SAMOA — As the federal government considers opening U.S. territorial waters to deep sea mining, Pacific Island communities and territorial governments are going on record to oppose the imposition of these activities, warning of irreversible harm to ocean ecosystems, cultural lifeways, and the democratic rights of island peoples.

Just hours before the comment period closes this week, Right to Democracy, in partnership with the America the Beautiful for All Coalition, will host a virtual panel examining the federal call to open the waters of the Marianas to deep sea mining and its implications for island communities, ocean ecosystems, and self-determination.

The panel will feature Andra Samoa, Maria Hernández, and Sheila Babauta, all of whom are Right to Democracy Environment & Democracy Fellows, and will be co-moderated by Neil Weare, Co-Director of Right to Democracy, and Angelo Villagomez, Ocean Co-Lead for the America the Beautiful for All Coalition.

Local and national civil society organizations will announce the results of their respective outreach efforts and successes in submitting petitions, letters, and comments to the federal register. 

Special guests include Lt. Governor Joshua Tenorio, Speaker Frank Blas, Jr., and others.

The Virtual Panel Will Take Place:

  •           Monday, January 12th at 5:00pm EST, 6:00pm AST, 11:00 am SST (American Samoa)
  •           Tuesday, January 13th at 8:00am ChST (Guam / Northern Mariana Islands)

 

 

Section: 
Local News
Tags: 
deep sea mining

Just hours before the comment period closes this week, Right to Democracy, in partnership with the America the Beautiful for All Coalition, will host a virtual panel examining the federal call to open the waters of the Marianas to deep sea mining and its implications for island communities, ocean ecosystems, and self-determination.
The panel will feature Andra Samoa, Maria Hernández, and Sheila Babauta, all of whom are Right to Democracy Environment & Democracy Fellows, and will be co-moderated by Neil Weare, Co-Director of Right to Democracy, and Angelo Villagomez, Ocean Co-Lead for the America the Beautiful for All Coalition.

item.title: Teacher shortage crisis deepens in Bougainville
item.description:
Bougainville’s education system is facing a severe teacher shortage, with more than 860 positions unfilled across the region, as officials announced the 2026 academic calendar this week.

Caretaker Secretary for Education Stanley Vavero confirmed the staffing gaps in a public update, detailing vacancies across all levels: 562 in elementary schools, 252 in primary schools, 9 in high schools, 3 in secondary schools, and 40 in vocational schools.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Teacher shortage crisis deepens in Bougainville appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: A new sea vessel for Atoll and Nissan Islanders
item.description:
Nissan and Atolls are the most remote constituencies of the North Bougainville electorate in the Autonomous Region of Bougainville.

Collectively, the islanders travel for up to 200 to 500km to reach Buka, sailing in open seas, precarious conditions and sustaining excessive transportation and fuel costs.

item.title: Obituaries for January 12
item.description: Randall Raynard Dudoit, 66, of Naalehu died Dec. 18 at home. Born in Honolulu, he was a carpenter, ranch hand and professional boxer. Services at a late date. Survived by wife, Pammy Dudoit; children, Randy Boy Alu, Pandalia (Mark Lazaar) Makuakane, Sabino “Bino” Makuakane and Keoni Kekoa (Erin Santos) Dudoit; mother, Rosita Esperago; siblings, Reuben Dudoit, Marcellus Dudoit Jr., Emma Dudoit Parham, Curtis Dudoit, Rosalind Dudoit Pegues, Manuel “Kalani” Dudoit, Sean Dudoit, Shane Dudoit, Landis Dudoit, Marroc Dudoit Kamai, Mannon Dudoit Kamai, Mandon Dudoit Kamai, Myndrene “Sachiko” Dudoit Kamai, Mahonn Dudoit Kamai and Mark Dudoit; seven grandchildren and five great-grandchildren; nieces, nephews, aunts, uncles and cousins. Arrangements by Dodo Mortuary.

item.title: Cuba defiant after Trump says island to receive no more Venezuelan oil or money
item.description: HAVANA/HOUSTON — President Donald Trump ‌on Sunday said no more Venezuelan oil or money will go to Cuba and suggested the Communist-run island should strike a deal with Washington, ramping up pressure on the long-time U.S. nemesis and provoking defiant words from the island’s leadership.
item.source:markdown: HAVANA/HOUSTON — President Donald Trump ‌on Sunday said no more Venezuelan oil or money will go to Cuba and suggested the Communist-run island should strike a deal with Washington, ramping up pressure on the long-time U.S. nemesis and provoking defiant words from the island’s leadership.

item.title: Chalamet beats DiCaprio at Hollywood’s Golden Globes
item.description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — ‌Timothee Chalamet triumphed in one of the most competitive categories at the Golden Globes on Sunday, taking the trophy for best male actor in a movie musical or comedy for his role as a professional table tennis player in “Marty Supreme.” Chalamet defeated Leonardo DiCaprio, George Clooney ‍and other big names at the red-carpet ceremony in Beverly Hills, California. “This category is stacked. I look up to all of you,” Chalamet said to his fellow nominees.
item.source:markdown: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — ‌Timothee Chalamet triumphed in one of the most competitive categories at the Golden Globes on Sunday, taking the trophy for best male actor in a movie musical or comedy for his role as a professional table tennis player in “Marty Supreme.” Chalamet defeated Leonardo DiCaprio, George Clooney ‍and other big names at the red-carpet ceremony in Beverly Hills, California. “This category is stacked. item.title: PM Marape calls on public servants to drive PNG’s Reset@50 through discipline, integrity and results
item.description:
Prime Minister James Marape has called on Papua New Guinea's public servants to take personal and institutional responsibility for driving the nation's Reset@50 agenda,warning that the country’s next 20 years will determine the future of generations to come.

Prime Minister James Marape address the 2026 Public Servants Dedication Service at the Sir John Guise Indoor Stadium, highlighting PNG has now stepped beyond its first 50 years of Independence and must enter a new era of discipline, delivery and national renewal.

item.title: Bulls power past Dons in pre-season opener
item.description:
Doncaster RLFC fell to a 12-30 defeat against Betfred Super League side Bradford Bulls at the Eco-Power Stadium in their sole warm-up fixture ahead of the 2026 Championship campaign.

Despite the "friendly" billing, the contest sparked to life early when Bradford’s Rowan Milnes was sin-pinned just seven minutes in for a high challenge. However, the man disadvantage didn't deter the visitors, who opened the scoring through Esan Marsters after a slick shift to the left flank.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Bulls power past Dons in pre-season opener appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: A Breezy Escape: 45 Minutes from Port Moresby to Gaire
item.description:
Sometimes all you need is a short drive away from the city to reset your mind, especially when you’re a local visitor based in Kiunga, Western Province, visiting Port Moresby.

On Friday, January 9, we took a roughly 45-minute drive out of the National Capital District, heading towards Gaire Village in Central Province for a relaxing getaway. It didn’t take long for the busy city atmosphere to fade behind us as the open road welcomed the promise of sea breeze and quiet moments.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post A Breezy Escape: 45 Minutes from Port Moresby to Gaire appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: Governor kicks off Governor’s Cup at Almami LLG, Bogia
item.description:
Madang Governor Ramsey Pariwa officially launched the Governor’s Cup at Almami Local Level Government in Bogia yesterday, with the opening ceremony held at the Malala Secondary School field.

Addressing players, officials, and supporters, Governor Pariwa described the occasion as a personal and meaningful return to Malala. He revealed he once attended Grades 11 and 12 at Malala Secondary School, crediting the school for shaping his education and leadership journey.

item.title: PNG Lewas arrive in Nepal ahead of ICC Women’s T20 Global Qualifiers
item.description:
The Papua New Guinea Lewas have safely arrived in Nepal, touching down yesterday, Sunday 12 January 2026, as preparations intensify for the ICC Women’s T20 World Cup Global Qualifier.

The tournament, which runs from 14 January to 1 February 2026, will be hosted at the TU Cricket Ground and Upper Hulpani Cricket Ground in Nepal, bringing together some of the world’s leading associate women’s teams as they compete for qualification to the ICC Women’s T20 World Cup England & Wales 2026.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

item.title: NICTA supports Public Service dedication program with 150 cartons of water
item.description:
With the National Public Service Dedication Program commencing this morning the National Information and Communications Technology Authority (NICTA) has donated 150 cartons of bottled water to the Department for Community Development and Religion in support of the Program.

On behalf of NICTA Acting Chief Executive Officer, Mr Lume Polume, the donation was delivered by Mr George Pondrelei and Ms Amanda Tito to Program Development Director, Mr George Kulisi, and Assistant Director for Religion, Mr Rex Hibuye last week.

item.title: Tens of thousands protest in Minneapolis over fatal ICE shooting
item.description: MINNEAPOLIS, Minn. — Tens of thousands of people marched through Minneapolis on Saturday to decry the fatal shooting of a woman ‌by a U.S. immigration agent, part of more than 1,000 rallies planned nationwide this weekend against the federal government’s deportation drive. The massive turnout in Minneapolis despite a whipping, cold wind underscores how the fatal shooting of 37-year-old Renee Good by an Immigration and Customs Enforce-ment officer on Wednesday has struck a chord, fueling protests in major cities and some towns. Minnesota’s Democratic leaders and the administration of President Donald Trump, a Republican, have offered starkly different accounts of the incident.
item.source:markdown: MINNEAPOLIS, Minn. — Tens of thousands of people marched through Minneapolis on Saturday to decry the fatal shooting of a woman ‌by a U.S. immigration agent, part of more than 1,000 rallies planned nationwide this weekend against the federal government’s deportation drive. The massive turnout in Minneapolis despite a whipping, cold wind underscores how the fatal shooting of 37-year-old Renee Good by an Immigration and Customs Enforce-ment officer on Wednesday has struck a chord, fueling protests in major cities and some towns. Minnesota’s Democratic leaders and the administration of President Donald Trump, a Republican, have offered starkly different accounts of the incident.

item.title: $100 billion to revive Venezuela’s energy industry? Oil executives are not so sure.
item.description: Exxon Mobil has a long history of drilling in challenging environments. The largest U.S. oil company will go almost anywhere to extract hydrocarbons if it can manage the risk and make the numbers work. Exxon pumps crude in the deep water off the coast of Guyana and has invested some $19 billion to produce natural gas on the island nation of Papua New Guinea.
item.source:markdown: Exxon Mobil has a long history of drilling in challenging environments. item.title: Obituaries for January 11
item.description: John E. Ambagis, 92, of Keaau died Jan. 2 at home. Born in New Haven, Conn., he was a retired psychotherapist specializing in children, police officer, world traveler and U.S. Navy Korean War-era veteran. Private services. Survived by wife, Mabel; sons, Johnny (Victoria) Ambagis, Kevin Ambagis, Jimmy (Regina) Ambagis, Joe (Cherisse) Ambagis, Jeffery (Chrissy) Ambagis and Stephen (Hilary) Ambagis; 13 grandchildren and 10 great grandchildren. Arrangements by Dodo Mortuary.

item.title: US may lift more Venezuela sanctions soon, Bessent says

item.title: Bird flu viruses raise mounting concerns among scientists
item.description: In the United States, the term bird flu has become synonymous with a particular virus that has devastated poultry and dairy farms over the past few years. But that virus, called H5N1, is not the only form of bird flu in circulation.

item.description: Aseries of lava fountains building a cone perched on the crater rim … sounds like the ongoing eruption in Halema‘uma‘u at the summit of Kilauea, but this description could also fit the Kilauea Iki eruption in 1959. Let’s compare these two episodic lava fountaining eruptions.

item.title: Cyclone winds topple power poles across Port Moresby; restoration efforts continue
item.description:
PNG Power Limited (PPL) technical teams are working through the night as a powerful weather system continues to batter the National Capital District, causing extensive damage to the city’s electrical grid.

As of 7:30 pm tonight, several major feeders remain out of service or are only partially restored following a day of destructive winds and heavy rain, triggered by the effects of a cyclone off the coast of Australia.

item.title: Bougainville Solar Plant generates first SOE revenue, lighting up Buin
item.description:
In a significant step toward economic self-reliance, the Bougainville Power and Water Corporation Limited (BPWCL) has begun generating its own revenue, becoming one of the first State-Owned Enterprises (SOEs) under the Autonomous Bougainville Government (ABG) to achieve this status.

This milestone follows the December commissioning of a one-megawatt solar power plant in Buin, South Bougainville. The plant now provides reliable electricity to approximately 250 households, schools, businesses, and health facilities in the town and its surrounding communities.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Bougainville Solar Plant generates first SOE revenue, lighting up Buin appeared first on Post Courier.

![](https://www.postcourier.com.pg/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/The-new-1-megawatt-solar-facility-in-Buin-now-supplies-clean-electricity-to-over-250-customers-1.png?w=800)

This milestone follows the December commissioning of a one-megawatt solar power plant in Buin, South Bougainville. The plant now provides reliable electricity to approximately 250 households, schools, businesses, and health facilities in the town and its surrounding communities.

item.title: Port Moresby battered by cyclonic winds: Major power restoration underway
item.description:
A major power restoration effort is currently underway across the National Capital District as PNG Power Limited (PPL) battles the destructive effects of a cyclone sitting off the coast of Australia.

As of 3:00 pm today, the city continues to experience fierce winds and heavy rains, which have toppled high-voltage poles, burnt out infrastructure, and sent tree branches crashing into power lines.

item.title: Report: Runway wall caused all deaths in S. Korean plane crash
item.description: SEOUL, South Korea — Everyone on board a Jeju Air flight that crashed and killed 179 people just over a year ago would have survived if a concrete wall at the end of the runway had instead been built with materials that break apart easily, a previously undisclosed report to the South Korean government said.

item.title: Plane crash scare at Kanabea Airstrip
item.description:
An SDA Aviation aircraft narrowly avoided a crash early this morning at the Kanabea Airstrip in Kotindanga Local Level Government (LLG), Gulf Province, raising fresh concerns over aviation safety in remote parts of the country.

The incident occurred at approximately 8:20 am as the aircraft was attempting to land while transporting the body of a senior nursing officer. Several family members escorting the remains were also on board.

item.title: Police condemn alleged compensation demands after Aumea Bridge collapse
item.description:
Business operations, including those of Ramu NiCo, have been disrupted following the collapse of the Aumea Bridge, which has severed a key section of the Madang–Lae–Highlands Highway.

Authorities are currently constructing a temporary wet crossing to allow traffic to resume while arrangements are made for the bridge to be rebuilt. The interim crossing is expected to restore access for commuters, freight operators, and businesses affected by the disruption.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

item.title: From Lae to Australia: How the PALM Scheme is changing lives
item.description:
When Markwin Awae boarded a flight from Lae to Australia three years ago, he carried more than just a suitcase. He carried the hopes of his family, the expectations of his community, and a fierce determination to build a better future.

Awae, who was born and raised in Lae City and hails from the Kabwum District of Morobe Province, is one of 91 workers deployed to Australia through the Lae Labour Mobility Unit under the Pacific Australia Labour Mobility (PALM) Scheme.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post From Lae to Australia: How the PALM Scheme is changing lives appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: Bishop warns against sea travel as strong wind alert hits Siassi waters
item.description:
ELCPNG Head Bishop Dr Jack Urame has warned delegates and the public against travelling by small boats to Siassi ahead of the Evangelical Lutheran Church of Papua New Guinea’s 2026 National Synod, citing serious safety concerns.

“This is a very challenging Synod because of the sea crossing,” Bishop Urame said. “We do not want to risk lives, and the church will not take responsibility if people travel in unsafe ways.”

item.title: Obituaries for January 9
item.description: Pilar Lucena De Mattos, 94, of Hilo died Dec. 26 at home. Born in Hawaii, she was a retired teacher at Laupahoehoe, Paauilo and Ookala schools. Private services. Survived by sons, Vernon De Mattos of Keaau, Marvin (Terry) De Mattos of Seattle and Shannon De Mattos of Las Vegas; daughter, Laura (Garrett) Balberde of Hilo; hanai sister, Edith Esteban of Hilo; brother-in-law, Juan Macanas of Pepeekeo; 10 grandchildren and 24 great-grandchildren; nieces and nephews. Arrangements by Dodo Mortuary.

item.title: Puma Energy says there is no petrol shortage at its pumps
item.description:
PUMA Energy PNG Limited is not experiencing petrol shortages but that its experience was of high demand in recent days, according to Head of Commercial Peter Blatch.

This follows grievances of petrol shortages today (morning hours) in Port Moresby, as vehicles and taxi services flocked to fuel service stations across the city for petrol.

item.title: NPL delivers first Tax Credit Scheme project with restoration of staff housing at Paiam Hospital
item.description:
New Porgera Limited (NPL) has successfully completed maintenance works on three staff houses, marking the first project delivered under the Infrastructure Tax Credit Scheme (TCS) since the restart of the New Porgera operation. The Paiam Hospital is the district hospital for the Porgera-Paiela District.

Funded through the TCS at a total cost of over K185,000, the maintenance works commenced in November 2025 and were completed on 31 December 2025.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post NPL delivers first Tax Credit Scheme project with restoration of staff housing at Paiam Hospital appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: Australia supports PNG to drive improvement in health systems
item.description:
The Australasian College of Health Service Management (ACHSM) and the PNG National Department of Health have signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) to drive improvement in healthcare systems in PNG.

The MOU signed at the annual Asia-Pacific Health Leadership Congress in Darwin establishes a collaborative partnership aimed at strengthening health leadership capacity across PNG. This will support Papua New Guinean health leaders to engage with regional and international peers, and progress the establishment of an official PNG branch of ACHSM.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Australia supports PNG to drive improvement in health systems appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: National Weather Service issue Gale warning for Southern Region
item.description:
THE Southern Region is expected to experience gale winds and rainfall up until late Saturday or early Sunday, said the PNG National Weather Service Assistant Director of Forecasting and Warning Benjamin Malai.

Mr Malai told the Post-Courier that the Southern Region, especially Western Province, Central, Gulf and Milne Bay are experiencing about 35 to 48 knots regarded as strong gale.

part of the global relay leading to the Commonwealth Games in Glasgow, Scotland in July
and August 2026.

March 2025, when His Majesty The King placed His Message to the first Baton.

item.title: King’s Baton arrives in Papua New Guinea to spark 2026 Commonwealth Games spirit
item.description:
The King’s Baton officially arrived in Papua New Guinea on Thursday, 8 January, marking a significant milestone in the 500-day global relay leading to the Glasgow 2026 Commonwealth Games.

 Originally sent forth by His Majesty The King from Buckingham Palace in March 2025, the Baton represents a tradition that connects and excites communities across the Commonwealth. This leg of the journey highlights the power of sport to inspire youth and strengthen international ties through inclusion and respect.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

item.title: A landmark road development project launched to transform Poroma, Nipa and Kutubu corridor
item.description:
Prime Minister James Marape has officially launched the long-awaited Poroma-Kutubu road sealing project, marking a historic turning point for a region that has served as Papua New Guinea’s economic engine for over three decades.

The K371.5 million project, part of the Connect PNG infrastructure program, aims to seal over 100 kilometers of highway, finally linking the remote oil-producing heartland to the rest of the nation with high-quality infrastructure.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

item.title: PNG Lewas register convincing win at Australian Country Championships
item.description:
The PNG Lewas continued their strong showing at the Toyota Australian Country Cricket Championships (Female Division) with a commanding 40-run victory over South Australia Country Women in a T20 match at Barossa Park, Lyndoch.

After winning the toss and electing to bat, the Lewas posted a competitive total of 133 for 7 from their allotted 20 overs. The batting effort was backed by a disciplined bowling display, with PNG restricting South Australia to 93 for 7 in 20 overs to seal a comfortable win.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post PNG Lewas register convincing win at Australian Country Championships appeared first on Post Courier.
item.source:markdown:
![](https://www.postcourier.com.pg/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/PNG-LEWAS-1.png?w=800)
The PNG Lewas continued their strong showing at the Toyota Australian Country Cricket Championships (Female Division) with a commanding 40-run victory over South Australia Country Women in a T20 match at Barossa Park, Lyndoch.
After winning the toss and electing to bat, the Lewas posted a competitive total of 133 for 7 from their allotted 20 overs. The batting effort was backed by a disciplined bowling display, with PNG restricting South Australia to 93 for 7 in 20 overs to seal a comfortable win.

item.title: Local leaders welcome King’s Baton to Hanuabada
item.description:
The 2026 Commonwealth Games King’s Baton Relay was met with a vibrant celebration today as it arrived in the historic stilt village of Hanuabada, the ancestral home of the Motu-Koitabu people.

National Capital District (NCD) Governor Powes Parkop was on hand to receive the Baton, marking a key milestone in the Port Moresby leg of the relay. The ceremony highlighted the village's unique sporting heritage, with the Baton at one point travelling by water to navigate the sprawling overwater.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Local leaders welcome King’s Baton to Hanuabada appeared first on Post Courier.
item.source:markdown:

The 2026 Commonwealth Games King’s Baton Relay was met with a vibrant celebration today as it arrived in the historic stilt village of Hanuabada, the ancestral home of the Motu-Koitabu people.

item.title: Obituaries for January 8
item.description: George Yuzuru Ikeda, 77, of Pahoa died Oct. 17 at Legacy Hilo Rehabilitation and Nursing Center. Born in Japan, he was a retired county Parks and Recreation district supervisor. Private services held. No flowers or koden (monetary gifts). Online condolences: dodomortuary.com. Survived by wife, Mae Ikeda of Pahoa; son, Reid (Anela) Ikeda of Hilo; brothers-in-law, Ronald Nakamoto of Hilo, Ray Nakamoto of Waimea and Alan (Joni) Nakamoto of Waikoloa; sisters-in-law, Ilona (Mark) Haggerty of Waimea, Doreen Nakamoto and Viola Alfson of California, Joyce Ikeda of Hilo; nephews and nieces. Arrangements by Dodo Mortuary.
item.source:markdown: George Yuzuru Ikeda, 77, of Pahoa died Oct. 17 at Legacy Hilo Rehabilitation and Nursing Center. Born in Japan, he was a retired county Parks and Recreation district supervisor. item.title: Yap State Influenza-Like Illness (ILI) Outbreak: Situational Report # 12
item.description: Thursday, January 08, 2026, /// DYCA PIO Yap FM - On Monday, December 8, 2025, Yap EpiNet declared an outbreak of influenza-like illnesses due to the increase in ILI incidences reported in the EpiWeek 49 report. An unusual increase in ILI was detected in the outer islands, namely Woleai Atoll, Lamotrek, and Elato, through ongoing monitoring by surveillance following the diarrheal outbreak. item.title: Jiwaka Township will experience power outage for maintenance work
item.description:
The township of Jiwaka in the Ramu Grid will experience an emergency power outage on Friday, January 9, 2026, from 9:00 am to 4:00 pm for maintenance work.

This power outage is due to maintenance work on a faulty tap on Kudjip's 66kV/22kV Transformer, which has been causing low voltage in the township area.

item.title: Continuous rain in Aitape demands prompt response from the Aitape-Lumi DDAC and West Sepik Disaster office
item.description:
Aitape Central LLG's ward 11 councilor Mr Benedict Moskem, is calling on the Aitape-Lumi District Development Authority and the West Sepik Provincial Disaster office for an immediate response to address excess flooding in his ward following the continuous rain in Aitape since last week.

The continuous rain has flooded most of the low-lying areas of ward 11, covering food gardens, overflowing toilet pits, and water wells, and it is a serious concern regarding the daily lives of people.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Continuous rain in Aitape demands prompt response from the Aitape-Lumi DDAC and West Sepik Disaster office appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: Governor Powes welcomes Post- Courier’s bold stand against gender based violence
item.description:
National Capital District (NCD) Governor and Chairman of the Parliamentary Committee on Gender Equality and Women’s Empowerment, Powes Parkop, has formally welcomed the Post-Courier’s decision to launch a weekly publication dedicated to the fight against gender-based violence (GBV).

The campaign, which will focus on promoting gender equality and women’s empowerment, is being hailed as a critical step in addressing one of Papua New Guinea's most deep-seated social crises.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Governor Powes welcomes Post- Courier’s bold stand against gender based violence appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: Governor General officially launches 2026 Commonwealth Games King’s Baton Relay in PNG
item.description:
PORT MORESBY – Governor General Sir Bob Dadai has officially launched the Papua New Guinea leg of the 2026 Commonwealth Games King’s Baton Relay, marking the start of a journey intended to inspire unity and national pride across the country.

During a formal ceremony at Government House, Sir Bob Dadai praised the collaborative effort required to host the historic event, extending his gratitude to government and diplomatic partners, sponsors, volunteers, and community leaders.

item.title: Ipatas Cup finals to ignite Lae city
item.description:
THE 20th edition of the National Gaming Control Board Ipatas Cup for the eight mainland provinces of Papua New Guinea has set the stage for each Gold Pass winner to face off in the elimination and grand final at the Lae Rugby League oval this weekend.

Tomorrow, will see the champions from the Eastern Highlands (Lisapeka Bulldogs) play the Simbu champions (Jaka Elimbari Miners), the Morobe champions (Morobe Pride) against the Western Highlands champions (Young Stars), then the Hela champions (Tari Central) against the reigning champions representing the Jiwaka Province (Kulaka West) and the main game between the Enga champs (Prum Panthers) and the Southern Highlands champs (Pepka Hawks).

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Ipatas Cup finals to ignite Lae city appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: Collapsed bridges disrupt business flow along Madang highway
item.description:
The collapse of two bridges along the Sir Bruce Jeffcott Highway has disrupted the flow of business to and from Lae and the Highlands to Madang Province.

The surging impacts of the Omiya and Yanamu rivers, respectively, caused by heavy downpours on Monday night, led to the collapse of the bridges named Omiya and Yanamu on Tuesday at 3 a.m., January 7, 2026.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

item.title: NARI, JICA partner to roll out SHEP Farming Project in East New Britain
item.description:
The National Agricultural Research Institute (NARI), in partnership with the Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA) and the East New Britain Provincial Government, has announced the implementation of the Project for Capacity Development of Sustainable Integrated Farming System using the SHEP Approach in East New Britain Province.

The project, which will be coordinated from NARI Keravat, will be rolled out across all four districts of the province. SHEP, or Smallholder Horticulture Empowerment Project, is designed to transform smallholder farming by shifting practices from the traditional “grow and sell” approach to a more market-oriented “grow to sell” strategy.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post NARI, JICA partner to roll out SHEP Farming Project in East New Britain appeared first on Post Courier.

SHEP, or Smallholder Horticulture Empowerment Project, is designed to transform smallholder farming by shifting practices from the traditional “grow and sell” approach to a more market-oriented “grow to sell” strategy.

item.title: Chris the walkabout salesman
item.description:
Christopher Molas Jnr is an entrepreneur with a knack for door-to-door sales. He makes up to K700-K800 selling everyday household items as a "travelling salesman" on the streets of Buka, Arawa, Buin and other locations in Bougainville.

Chris hails from Lemankoa, Haku Constituency and Wakunai in the Rau Constituency of Central Bougainville. He started his "liklik bisnis" in 2018 and fondly recalls being drawn into entrepreneurship by friends and relatives who were actively involved in the informal sector.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

item.title: AROB mourns the passing Bougainville Boundaries Commissioner
item.description:
Bougainville is mourning the loss of a vibrant and charismatic civil servant and patriot, the Late John Sisiesi - Acting Commissioner of the Bougainville Boundaries Commission. 

News of his death has been met by profound sadness by all who knew him; as it was formally announced to the public today in Buka by family representatives Andrew Sisiesi and Chris Siriosi who confirmed his untimely passing in the early hours of Tuesday morning, at his family home.

item.title: Five years on, Trump keeps pushing Jan. 6 conspiracies

item.title: Venezuela to ‘turn over’ up to 50 million barrels of crude to the US, Trump says
item.description: WASHINGTON — Caracas and Washington have reached a deal to export up to $2 billion worth of Venezuelan crude to the United States, President Donald Trump said Tuesday, a flagship negotiation that would divert supplies from China while helping Venezuela avoid deeper oil production cuts.
item.source:markdown: WASHINGTON — Caracas and Washington have reached a deal to export up to $2 billion worth of Venezuelan crude to the United States, President Donald Trump said Tuesday, a flagship negotiation that would divert supplies from China while helping Venezuela avoid deeper oil production cuts.

item.title: Health Dept. to freeze $10 billion in funding to 5 Democratic states
item.description: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration plans to freeze $10 billion in funding for child care subsidies, social services and cash support for low-income families in five states controlled by Democrats, claiming widespread fraud throughout those states, without citing evidence, after a major welfare fraud scheme in one of them.
item.source:markdown: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration plans to freeze $10 billion in funding for child care subsidies, social services and cash support for low-income families in five states controlled by Democrats, claiming widespread fraud throughout those states, without citing evidence, after a major welfare fraud scheme in one of them.

item.description: The trial of one ​of the first police officers on the ‌scene of the 2022 attack at a Texas elementary school that killed 19 students and two teachers opened ‌on Tuesday, with prosecutors accusing him of criminally failing to try to stop the slaughter, while the defense said the officer did the best he could at the chaotic and confusing scene.

item.title: Zelenskyy’s assessment darkens as Europeans gather to talk peace
item.description: KYIV, Ukraine — As Ukraine peace talks have stretched on for nearly a year, through fits and spurts and dozens of rounds, President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has accentuated the positive. The talks are now “90% complete,” he said. Ukraine works every minute to end the war, he insisted.
item.source:markdown: KYIV, Ukraine — As Ukraine peace talks have stretched on for nearly a year, through fits and spurts and dozens of rounds, President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has accentuated the positive. The talks are now “90% complete,” he said. Ukraine works every minute to end the war, he insisted.

item.title: Venezuela under Maduro shipped gold worth $5.2 billion to Switzerland
item.description: ZURICH — Venezuela transported gold worth almost 4.14 billion Swiss francs ($5.20 billion) ​to Switzerland during the ‌early years of the leadership of ousted President Nicolas ‌Maduro, customs data shows.
item.source:markdown: ZURICH — Venezuela transported gold worth almost 4.14 billion Swiss francs ($5.20 billion) ​to Switzerland during the ‌early years of the leadership of ousted President Nicolas ‌Maduro, customs data shows.

item.title: Maduro opponent Machado vows to return to Venezuela, wants an election
item.description: WASHINGTON — Venezuela’s main opposition leader, Maria Corina Machado, has vowed to return home quickly, praising U.S. President Donald Trump for toppling ‌her enemy Nicolas Maduro and declaring her movement ready to win a free election. Trump appears, however, to hope for now to work with interim President Delcy Rodriguez and other senior officials from Maduro’s government, disappointing the opposition and contributing to nervousness in Venezuela. Venezuelan and U.S. officials are discussing the export of Venezuelan crude to U.S. refiners, five government, industry and shipping sources told Reuters. “I’m planning to go back to Venezuela as soon as possible,” said Machado, 58, who escaped from Venezuela in disguise in October to receive the Nobel Peace Prize, which she dedicated to Trump.
item.source:markdown: WASHINGTON — Venezuela’s main opposition leader, Maria Corina Machado, has vowed to return home quickly, praising U.S. President Donald Trump for toppling ‌her enemy Nicolas Maduro and declaring her movement ready to win a free election. Trump appears, however, to hope for now to work with interim President Delcy Rodriguez and other senior officials from Maduro’s government, disappointing the opposition and contributing to nervousness in Venezuela. Venezuelan and U.S. officials are discussing the export of Venezuelan crude to U.S. refiners, five government, industry and shipping sources told Reuters. “I’m planning to go back to Venezuela as soon as possible,” said Machado, 58, who escaped from Venezuela in disguise in October to receive the Nobel Peace Prize, which she dedicated to Trump.

item.title: Stray bullet hits PNG Power headquarters in Port Moresby
item.description:
PNG Power Limited (PPL) has confirmed that a bullet struck the glass frontage of its headquarters building in Port Moresby on Tuesday night, 6 January 2026, in an incident that occurred after business hours.

According to the company, the incident took place at approximately 10:00pm at the PNG Power Ltd Head Office, specifically near the Properties Office area. No staff were present at the time and no injuries were reported.

item.title: North Bougainville MP Francesca Semoso delivers K1 million worth of medical equipment and infrastructure to Buka General Hospital
item.description:
North Bougainville MP and Assistant Speaker of the National Parliament, Francesca Rianna Semoso, has handed over a range of essential medical equipment, vehicles, and infrastructure improvements valued at part of a K2 million commitment to Buka General Hospital, emphasising her ongoing support for strengthening healthcare services in the region.

In a ceremony witnessed by key health officials and community leaders, Ms Francesca Semoso presented the items on behalf of her K2 million funding allocation presented earlier on 16 May 2025. The handover was received by the Minister for Health and North Bougainville Women's Representative, Delourdes Semoso, alongside Buka General Hospital CEO Dr. Tommy Wotsia. Also present were Acting Health Secretary Mr. Matthew Monei, Tsitalato Constituency Member, Mr John Bosco Ragu, Buka Town Manager, Mr. Fidelis Semoso, chairpersons of the Community Government, and members of the general public.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post North Bougainville MP Francesca Semoso delivers K1 million worth of medical equipment and infrastructure to Buka General Hospital appeared first on Post Courier.

In a ceremony witnessed by key health officials and community leaders, Ms Francesca Semoso presented the items on behalf of her K2 million funding allocation presented earlier on 16 May 2025. The handover was received by the Minister for Health and North Bougainville Women's Representative, Delourdes Semoso, alongside Buka General Hospital CEO Dr. Tommy Wotsia. Also present were Acting Health Secretary Mr. Matthew Monei, Tsitalato Constituency Member, Mr John Bosco Ragu, Buka Town Manager, Mr. Fidelis Semoso, chairpersons of the Community Government, and members of the general public.

item.title: PNG Correctional Services officers complete NSW study tour
item.description:
A team of senior officers from Papua New Guinea Correctional Services (PNGCS), led by Acting Commissioner Bernard Nepo, has completed a week-long study tour in New South Wales, Australia, aimed at strengthening correctional services in Papua New Guinea.

The study tour was supported by the Australia–PNG Law and Justice Partnership and hosted by Corrective Services NSW (CSNSW). During the visit, officers were exposed to a range of correctional operations, including custodial management, rehabilitation programmes, community-based corrections, specialised security protocols, and prison industries.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post PNG Correctional Services officers complete NSW study tour appeared first on Post Courier.
item.source:markdown:
![](https://www.postcourier.com.pg/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/PNG-CS.png?w=800)

item.title: What lies beneath: The wealth beneath the Marianas waves
item.description: Seamount crusts/Photo courtesy of NOAA According to the U.S. Geological Survey, the following minerals are likely present in the CNMI waters: Cobalt-rich iron-manganese crusts occur on the sea­mounts located east of the Mariana Trench. Data for crusts from nearby seamounts indicate that crusts on sea­mounts within that sector of the CNMI EEZ have an excel­lent potential to be thick and have high contents of cobalt, nickel, and platinum. It is recommended that these sea­mounts be explored...
item.source:markdown: Seamount crusts/Photo courtesy of NOAA According to the U.S. Geological Survey, the following minerals are likely present in the CNMI waters: Cobalt-rich iron-manganese crusts occur on the sea­mounts located east of the Mariana Trench. Data for crusts from nearby seamounts indicate that crusts on sea­mounts within that sector of the CNMI EEZ have an excel­lent potential to be thick and have high contents of cobalt, nickel, and platinum. It is recommended that these sea­mounts be explored...

item.title: Gold rush in the deep or a looming catastrophe?
item.description: The surging demand for critical minerals—driven primarily by the global energy transition and digital technology—has fueled President Donald Trump’s ambition to outpace China in this emerging trillion-dollar industry.

item.title: Cautious criticism and silence: the Indo-Pacific react to Maduro’s capture
item.description: On Jan. 2, the U.S. led a covert mission to capture and arrest Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro and his wife. After weeks of sabre-rattling and military buildups in the Caribbean, elite U.S military personnel carried out a secret operation that was months in the making.

item.title: Kurtistown woman dies after alleged assault in Kawaihae; suspect could be charged with murder or manslaughter
item.description: A 40-year-old Kurtistown woman who died Sunday morning after being punched Saturday night in Kawaihae — during an incident in which she allegedly used a motor vehicle as a weapon — had a history of impaired driving, according to court records.

item.title: Feds: Sex crimes against Hawaii kids up since 2021
item.description: Federal prosecutions of pedophilia and crimes against children in Hawaii increased by 50% between 2024 and last year, and by 150% since 2021, according to the U.S. Department of Justice.

item.title: Maduro pleads not guilty to drug charges, saying he was ‘kidnapped’
item.description: NEW YORK — Toppled ‌Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro pleaded not guilty on Monday to narcotics charges after President Donald Trump’s stunning capture of him rattled world leaders and left officials in Caracas scrambling to regroup.

item.title: Obituaries for January 6
item.description: Byron Keali‘ihelepo Ayoso 71, of Hilo died Nov. 21 at Hilo Benioff Medical Center. Born in Kohala, he was a U.S. Air Force retiree. Visitation 10-11 a.m. Monday, Jan. 26 2026, at The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 55-524 Hawi Rd. in Hawi. Military honors 11:30 a.m-noon with burial to follow Wednesday, Jan. 28, at East Hawaii Veterans Cemetery No. 2 in Hilo. Online condolences: homelanimemorialpark.com. Survived by wife, Amanda Ayoso of Hilo; six children; 14 grandchildren; other family. Arrangements by Homelani Memorial Park.

item.title: Pentagon to cut Senator Kelly’s military retirement pay, alleging ‘reckless misconduct’
item.description: WASHINGTON — President Donald Trump’s Pentagon ‌chief announced plans on Monday to demote U.S. Senator Mark Kelly from his rank as a retired Navy captain for alleged “reckless misconduct” after he and other Democratic lawmakers urged troops to refuse any illegal orders.

item.title: Trump’s threat of force against Colombia draws rebuke from its leader

item.title: Gov. Tim Walz drops reelection bid, and Amy Klobuchar may run instead
item.description: ST. PAUL, Minn. — Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota said Monday that he was abandoning his bid for reelection to a third term. And Sen. Amy Klobuchar, a fellow Democrat, is considering seeking the office, two people briefed on conversations between the two politicians said.

item.title: Betelnut chewing and smoking ban enforced in Madang CBD
item.description:
The restriction on betelnut chewing and smoking in public places in the Madang Central Business District is a national law and not a policy of the Madang Urban Local Level Government.

Madang Governor and Provincial Member Ramsey Pariwa clarified this following recent arrests in Madang town after enforcement began on Thursday, January 1, 2026. Governor Pariwa said the law was enacted by Parliament and carries the same legal weight and penalties as other national laws.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Betelnut chewing and smoking ban enforced in Madang CBD appeared first on Post Courier.
item.source:markdown:

item.title: PM Marape: Fisheries can anchor PNG’s economic independence as Daru Command Centre is commissioned
item.description:
Prime Minister, James Marape, declares that the fisheries sector has the potential to anchor up to half of Papua New Guineas economy as he authorized the National Fisheries Authority Monitoring, Control and Surveillance (MCS) command center in Daru.

At the peak of the occasion, Marape described the fisheries sector as a strategic pillar in PNG’s journey towards full economic independence, as he addressed national and provincial leaders, development partners and local communities.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post PM Marape: Fisheries can anchor PNG’s economic independence as Daru Command Centre is commissioned appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: Police urge formal complaint over alleged assault case
item.description:
Madang Provincial Police Commander Superintendent Robert Baim has urged the public to formally report alleged cases of police brutality instead of relying only on Facebook posts.

His comments follow a social media post titled “Enough is enough: Police brutality must stop”, which alleges that a uniformed police officer assaulted a local man in his 50s on 2 January 2026 near a supermarket in the Ramu area.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Police urge formal complaint over alleged assault case appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: PM Marape launches National Fisheries Surveillance Command Centre to protect PNG’s sovereignty and marine wealth
item.description:
Prime Minister James Marape has officially opened a new fisheries surveillance centre in Daru, Western Province, marking a major step in protecting Papua New Guinea's marine resources and sovereignty.

The launching of the National Fisheries Authority's (NFA) Monitoring, Control and Surveillance (MCS) Command Centre in Daru is a major milestone aimed at safeguarding the country's marine resources, sovereignty and future economic security.

item.title: Teachers to resume duties ahead of Students in 2026
item.description:
The Department of Education has announced that teachers will resume their duties earlier than students to prepare for the upcoming academic year.

In a circular released by the department , teachers across the country are advised that they will officially resume duties on Monday, January 19, 2026. Students are scheduled to begin classes one week later, on Monday, January 26, 2026.

item.title: PM commends communities and security forces for peaceful festive season
item.description:
Prime Minister James Marape has commended Papua New Guineans across the country for maintaining relative peace and order during the 2025 Christmas and New Year festive period, describing the overall national conduct as “better than most years” and an encouraging start to the nation’s next 50 years.

The Prime Minister said reports received at the start of the working year indicated that, aside from a small number of alcohol-fuelled incidents and isolated New Year disturbances, the festive season had been largely calm across all provinces, including the Autonomous Region of Bougainville.

item.title: Cash-trapping scam discovered on local bank ATM
item.description:
By 
Samoa News staff
reporters@samoanews.com

Pago Pago, AMERICAN SAMOA — Customers of the Territorial Bank of American Samoa (TBAS) have been actively voicing their concerns on social media about a troubling cash-trapping scheme reported at the bank's Automated Teller Machine (ATM) located within the Laufou Shopping Center in Nuʻuuli. 

Several social media accounts have surfaced, detailing allegations that certain individuals have strategically applied tape to the ATM’s cash dispenser. This disturbing tactic is designed to misappropriate customer withdrawals. One account described a troubling incident in which a customer attempted to withdraw funds from an ATM. Although he received a receipt indicating that the transaction was successful, he was shocked to find that no physical cash was dispensed. Upon closer inspection of the cash dispenser, he discovered tape blocking the exit, with the cash he had attempted to withdraw stuck to it.

This alarming incident has since been reported to TBAS management. Cash-trapping scams have become a troubling trend, reported in communities across the United States and internationally. These schemes typically involve placing a device or obstruction over the cash dispenser slot to prevent the release of funds. In these scenarios, the customer’s account is debited, yet no cash is dispensed. Victims often assume the ATM is malfunctioning and leave, allowing the perpetrator to return, remove the obstruction, and claim the trapped cash.

In response to these concerns, TBAS President and Chief Executive Officer Owen Perry addressed local media, confirming the bank's awareness of the troubling reports. He indicated that TBAS is actively investigating the situation, which appears to be limited to this ATM location for now. “Upon learning about the issue, the bank quickly contacted the Department of Public Safety and is cooperating fully while conducting an internal review,” Perry stated.

Perry further emphasized, “Our ATMs undergo regular monitoring and inspections, and we are continually evaluating and enhancing our security protocols across all locations.” TBAS strongly encourages any customer who experiences difficulties at a TBAS ATM or notices any anomalies to contact the bank immediately, enabling a swift response and resolution.

Due to the ongoing investigation, Perry noted that the bank cannot share specific details about the incidents at this time. “Our top priority is to ensure the safety of our customers while maintaining the integrity of our banking services,” he remarked.

 

 

Section: 
Local News
Tags: 
cash trapping scam
item.source:markdown:
[![CASH TRAPPING ](https://www.samoanews.com/sites/default/files/styles/slideshow/public/field/image/cash_trapping_examples.jpg?itok=A10eMQF3)](https://www.samoanews.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_normal_image/public/field/image/cash_trapping_examples.jpg?itok=uHKEcqoy)

Upon closer inspection of the cash dispenser, he discovered tape blocking the exit, with the cash he had attempted to withdraw stuck to it.
This alarming incident has since been reported to TBAS management. Cash-trapping scams have become a troubling trend, reported in communities across the United States and internationally. item.description: J Across Guam and the wider Western Pacific, the ocean is more than geography; it is livelihood, culture, and legacy. item.title: Solar-powered water upgrade for Yanga Village
item.description:
Residents of Yanga Village near Lae can now enjoy improved access to clean and reliable water after Ahi Investment Limited funded the repair and upgrade of the community’s bore water system.

The project, delivered through the Ahi Charitable Trust, restored a damaged water tank and upgraded the system using solar-powered technology. The bore water system was originally donated by the Lae City Authority, but one of its tanks was damaged and became non-functional, affecting water supply for the village.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Solar-powered water upgrade for Yanga Village appeared first on Post Courier.
item.source:markdown:
![](https://www.postcourier.com.pg/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/feature-picture-17.png?w=800)

item.title: New Ambulance for Lato Constituency
item.description:
Lato Constituency in South Bougainville is making significant progress in efforts to boost ambulatory emergency care and rural healthcare, as seen with the unveiling of a brand new ambulance by Minister for Community Development and Member for Lato Constituency, Melvin Wilolopa.

Minister Wilolopa announced the timely "New Year's gift" to constituents, stating that his people would no longer be denied access to essential transportation for urgent medical care.

item.title: Letter to the Editor: Your vote carries more weight than you know
item.description: While we are just a few days into the new year, we are well into the 2026 Guam election cycle. Many different organizations will be pushing hard to get folks to the polls and cast their vote for those candidates who they believe best represent today’s issues and those of the foreseeable future. Whether these organizations are faith-based, service-oriented, business, philanthropic or political, the arguments will be made for and against candidates all who can best take care of those issues...

item.title: Two foreigners on the run after allegedly stealing money
item.description:
TWO Bangladeshi man are on the run after they allegedly stole money and company documents from their employer.

Owner and managing director of Al-Rafi Trading Limited in Goroka, Eastern Highlands Province, Siful Mondol reported that the two committed the offence on December 20, 2025 in Lae, Morobe province, while he was away in Bangladesh visiting his family.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

item.title: New Guinea’s forests
item.description:
New Guinea is staggeringly rich in life. Occupying just 0.5% of Earth’s land surface, it hosts an estimated 5-8% of all species. This abundance is reflected in more than 2,800 orchid species, over 1,000 butterflies and around 800 birds. Over half of its known species are found nowhere else on Earth.

The post New Guinea’s forests appeared first on Post Courier.
item.source:markdown:
![](https://www.postcourier.com.pg/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/FOCUS.png?w=800)
New Guinea is staggeringly rich in life. Occupying just 0.5% of Earth’s land surface, it hosts an estimated 5-8% of all species. This abundance is reflected in more than 2,800 orchid species, over 1,000 butterflies and around 800 birds. Over half of its known species are found nowhere else on Earth.

item.title: Four doctors houses under construction at Tambul Station
item.description:
Four new residential houses for doctors are currently under construction at Tambul Station, in a move aimed at improving accommodation and working conditions for medical professionals serving the area.

The project is being implemented under the leadership of local Member of Parliament, Win Bakri Daki, as part of broader efforts to strengthen healthcare services in Tambul and surrounding communities.

item.title: Kerema to host Papua LNG Forum despite landowner objections
item.description:
Kerema Town has been confirmed as the host venue for the upcoming Papua LNG Development Forum, despite calls from some landowners for the meeting to be relocated to Port Moresby over safety and health concerns.

Member for Kerema and Minister for Finance Thomas Opa has assured all stakeholders that comprehensive planning and resourcing are already in place to ensure the successful hosting of the nationally significant forum.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Kerema to host Papua LNG Forum despite landowner objections appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: US strike on Venezuela to embolden China’s territorial claims, analysts say

item.title: Trump says U.S. will run Venezuela after U.S. captures Maduro
item.description: WASHINGTON (Reuters) — U.S. President Donald Trump said ​on Saturday he was putting Venezuela under temporary American control after ‌the United States captured President Nicolas Maduro in an audacious raid and whisked him to New York to face drug-trafficking charges.
item.source:markdown: WASHINGTON (Reuters) — U.S. President Donald Trump said ​on Saturday he was putting Venezuela under temporary American control after ‌the United States captured President Nicolas Maduro in an audacious raid and whisked him to New York to face drug-trafficking charges.

item.title: Democrats raise alarms after Trump avoids congressional approval for Maduro’s capture
item.description: WASHINGTON — Republicans in Congress on Saturday cheered the Trump administration’s dramatic military action to capture President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela, but top Democrats sounded alarms about the legality of the operation and said they would seek a quick vote to halt hostilities without express authorization.
item.source:markdown: WASHINGTON — Republicans in Congress on Saturday cheered the Trump administration’s dramatic military action to capture President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela, but top Democrats sounded alarms about the legality of the operation and said they would seek a quick vote to halt hostilities without express authorization.

item.title: Managers of Swiss bar are suspected of negligence in deadly fire, police say
item.description: CRANS-MONTANA, Switzerland — The two managers of a bar in the Swiss Alps where at least 40 people died in a sudden fire early New Year’s Day have been placed under criminal investigation because of allegations of negligence, police said Saturday, as authorities in Switzerland come under growing pressure to explain whether flaws in the site’s design and management fueled the disaster.
item.source:markdown: CRANS-MONTANA, Switzerland — The two managers of a bar in the Swiss Alps where at least 40 people died in a sudden fire early New Year’s Day have been placed under criminal investigation because of allegations of negligence, police said Saturday, as authorities in Switzerland come under growing pressure to explain whether flaws in the site’s design and management fueled the disaster.

item.title: Airlines canceling flights after the US closes Caribbean airspace
item.description: U.S. airlines canceled flights, and air travel was disrupted Saturday after federal aviation authorities shut down U.S.-controlled airspace over the Caribbean in response to a U.S. military operation in Venezuela that resulted in the capture of the country’s president.
